main-text.text: State Capitol P.O. Box 2062 Albany, NY 12220-0062 www.its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The purpose of this standard is to establish controls for 802.11 wireless networks in order to minimize risks to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of State Entity's (SE) information and to support secure access to such information and State Information Technology Resources and services over SE wireless networks.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 802.11 wireless networks enable users of wireless devices the flexibility to physically move throughout a wireless environment while maintaining connectivity to the network. While 802.11 wireless networks are exposed to many of the same risks as wired networks, they are also exposed to additional risks unique to wireless technologies. This standard outlines the additional controls required for the use of wireless networks by SEs.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides the Office of Information Technology Services (ITS) with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 1 , issued January 2002, provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: $^{1}$ All references to Executive Order 117 refer to that which was originally issued by Governor George E. Pataki on January 28, 2002 and continued by Executive Order 5 issued by Governor Eliot Spitzer on January 1, 2007, Executive Order 9 issued by Governor David A. Patterson on June 18, 2008, Executive Order 2 issued by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo on January 1, 2011 and Executive Order 6 issued by Governor Kathy Hochul on October 8, 2021.
main-text.name: Footnote

main-text.text: and business re-engineering. Details regarding this authority can be found in NYS ITS Policy, NYS-P08-002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines .
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This standard applies to all "State Entities" ("SE"), defined as "State Government" entities in Executive Order 117 or "State Agencies" as defined in Section 101 of the State Technology Law. This includes employees and all other third parties (such as local governments, consultants, vendors, and contractors), that use or access any ITS Information Technology Resource for which ITS has administrative responsibility, including systems managed or hosted by third parties on behalf of the ITS. While an SE may adopt a different standard, it must include the requirements set forth in this one.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This standard applies to all 802.11 wireless networks that store, process, or transmit SE information or connect to an SE network or system, including networks managed and hosted by third parties on behalf of the State.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The types of 802.11 wireless networks in scope include:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Internal - these SE wireless networks are directly connected to the State's internal Information Technology Resources and are only available to authenticated users.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Public (authenticated) - these SE wireless networks are not connected to the State's internal Information Technology Resources and access is limited to authenticated users.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Public (non-authenticated) - these SE wireless networks are not connected to the State's internal Information Technology Resources and are available for anyone to use without authentication.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 1. 802.11 wireless networks must follow all requirements of the NYS-P03-002 NYS Information Security Policy including, but not limited to, a risk assessment prior to implementation.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2. All wireless installations must be authorized by the management of the SE whose information will traverse the wireless network.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 3. Security plan documentation, as required by the NYS-S15-003 Secure System Development Lifecycle Standard, must include, at a minimum, the SE name, all Access Point (AP) locations, all supporting wireless infrastructure locations, the subnet on the wired network, and the Service Set Identifier (SSID).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4. APs and other supporting wireless devices must be placed in physically protected locations that minimize the opportunity for theft, damage, or unauthorized access.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Page 2 of 5
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: 5. Wireless network coverage must be managed to restrict the ability to connect outside of the SE-approved boundary.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 6. The SSID of 802.11 wireless networks must be changed from the factory default setting.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 7. The SSID must not include information that indicates the location, technology, or manufacturer details of the wireless network (e.g., Server-Rm-WiFi-Access, WifiRm70 and Cisco-2400-WiFi). The SSID also must not include information that indicates the type of data traversing the network.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 8. A wireless Intrusion Detection System (IDS) must be utilized on all SE internal wireless networks.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 9. Public wireless networks (authenticated and non-authenticated) must be, at a minimum, physically separated from the internal wireless network or configured to tunnel to a secure endpoint outside the internal wireless network. The design must be included in the documented security plan.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 10. Logical addressing schemas must be used for public wireless (authenticated and non-authenticated), internal wireless, and wired networks in order to effectively distinguish client connections between them.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 11. While servers and information stores may be accessible over a wireless network, they must not directly connect to any wireless network.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 12. APs on public authenticated or internal wireless networks must be configured to provide the strongest encryption settings available. At a minimum, Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA) 2 - Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) must be utilized.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 13. WPA2 personal mode must not be used for SE internal wireless networks.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 14. WPA2 personal mode, with Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPS) disabled, may be used for public authenticated access points that do not connect to SE internal wireless networks.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 15. APs which utilize passphrases (such as APs configured to use WPA2 personal mode) must use passphrases that conform to the NYS Authentication Tokens Standard and must be at least 14 characters in length and changed at a minimum every six months.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 16. Passphrases used by APs must be changed from the factory default setting.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 17. Administrative access to any wireless network devices (APs, routers, etc.) must not be allowed from any wireless network. All administrative access must be done via the wired network.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 18. 802.1X authentication, specifically the Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP), must be used for all devices connecting to SE internal wireless networks. SEs must use the EAP-TLS (Transport Layer Security) method whenever possible. Use of
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Page 3 of 5
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Lightweight EAP (LEAP) or any of the following EAP authentication mechanisms is not allowed: EAP-MD5 (Message Digest), EAP-OTP (One Time Password), and EAP-GTC (Generic Token Card).
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 19. Wireless devices that connect to SE internal wireless networks must be configured to validate certificates issued by the authentication server during the authentication process.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 20. Wireless devices must be configured to utilize identity privacy settings during the authentication process, where technically feasible.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 21. Individual user authentication is required for SE internal wireless networks, in accordance with the NYS-S14-006 Authentication Tokens Standard.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This standard shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is required with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If compliance with this standard is not feasible or technically possible, or if deviation from this policy is necessary to support a business function, State Entities shall request an exception through the Chief Information Security Office exception process.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http://www.its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 7.0 Contact Information
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Submit all inquiries and requests for future enhancements to the policy owner at:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Chief Information Security Office Reference: NYS-S15-003 NYS Office of Information Technology Services 1220 Washington Avenue, Building 5 Albany, NY 12226
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Email: CISO@its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 4 of 5
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Statewide technology policies, standards, and guidelines may be found at the following website: http://www.its.ny.gov/tables/technologypolicyindex
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 8.0 Revision History
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This standard shall be reviewed at least once every year to ensure relevancy.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Section-header
